experience: You and Ian both know John Furrier, James Cossler, and 64 others
Lately, I have had some (237ish) requests from frustrated candidates about the “big picture” of recruiting:
We’re going to do an old fashioned #jonstewart as #glennbeck “follow the money.”
Not paying anything or getting anything: Candidate
You, the Candidate are NOT the Client.
Recruiting is a service like any other service. If recruiting was a haircut, the recruiter would be the hairdresser, the client would be the one getting the haircut and YOU, the candidate?
You? Well, you are the gosh darn scissors. A very, shiny, special, exotic kind of sciossors that the client can only dream about finding on their own.
You’re the tool/method from which the servicer (recruiter) delivers the service to the client (company hiring).
As a bonus to this you can be introduced to entire new careers and opportunities that you never knew existed or that you were qualified for.
That’s WAY better than being a pair of scissors.
And recruiters should treat you, your career and your next opportunity with the respect you deserve because you are not scissors. You are a person.
But in the end: FOLLOW the MONEY, Honey.
My father was a erratic alcoholic.

Throughout my childhood he would purchase, then proceed to throw away, various television sets. He viewed television as a waste of time and his self-loathing after spending an afternoon on the couch affected all of us.
It was a blessing and a curse. As a middle child, I retreated into literature. I read. Everything.
At 7 I finished Les Misérables. By 8th grade I tested at college level reading comprehension.

My “success” on this platform is in no way related to my personal business savvy, or financial or social gain. It's purely a result of my ability to write, gleaned from a life of hiding away from my father’s rage.
That being said, I am no better or different than any of you. We are a product of our circumstances.
I know successful people are viewed differently. Possibly glorified.
But our successes and failures are so often ingrained. And sometimes they come from dark places.
What is your source of success?
Don't let age or responsibilities ever get in the way of continuing to learn new skills and improve yourself.

Good morning! I am inundated with messages from folks asking me to hire them for programming gigs, even though I am unemployed developer myself. Is anybody else having this same experience? It's frustrating to be mobbed by spam here while I'm relying on this platform for actual communication from recruiters and employers.

Junior data scientists: I know that many of you are frustrated by the difficulting in breaking into our field. But in light of the Thanksgiving holiday, I encourage you to consider how fortunate we are to have such a wealth of information at our fingertips.
We have easy access to high-quality training in machine learning techniques thanks to people like Kirill Eremenko, @Jose Marcial Portilla, and the good folks at Metis (Jason Moss).
There's a number of people providing guidance on the non-technical aspects of data science such as myself, @Eric Weber, Vin Vashishta, Carla Gentry, and others.

My message to you is to keep at it. You won't get hired right away—and that's okay. And trying to "crush" an interview should not be your goal (a topic for a future blog post from me). Just take what you have—keep learning!—and present yourself to the best of your ability to employers. They do need your skills.
And the rewards are worth the effort you are doing. This truly is the sexiest job of the 21st century.
Why is there always such an emphasis on hiring new software developers?
More developers WILL create more BAD CODE.
The more BAD CODE you add the less work is done!
9 women CANNOT have a baby in 1 month.
It's flawed to focus on the hocus pocus management vanity metrics.
Companies should focus first on IMPROVING existing code so that the work rate per developer goes UP not DOWN.
Focus on letting developers create GOOD code.
The first Windows phone needed 300 hundred engineers.
